sen.e: Kenshi OKUNOMIYA (December 27, 1857 - January 24, 1911) was a social movement activist in Japan, who played an active part during Jiyu Minken Undo (the Freedom and People's Rights Movement).

sen.e: Because the speech delivered at the Asakusa Imura-ro had resulted in the restriction of freedom of speech within Tokyo Prefecture, Kenshi obtained a lecturer's license to appear at a vaudeville hall under the stage name "Senseido Kakumei" and advocated liberty and people's rights through his oral storytelling; he was punished for the speech along with the host of vaudeville hall and was sentenced to one month of brief imprisonment for violating the Public Assembly Law.

sen.e: When he noticed the Tokyo Horse Tramway construction had left rickshaw men out of work, he persuaded Mo TAKEUCHI's personal rickshaw leader, Kamekichi SANPO, to act as his agent and distribute handbills that promised unlimited cups of sake to anyone gathered, and on October 4th, 1882, he held a big get-together party for rickshaw men within the precincts of the Kanda-Myojin Shrine.

Focusing on rickshaw men who lost their jobs after the Tokyo Horse Tramway was laid, he persuaded Tsuna TAKEUCHI's rickshaw chauffeur and leader of rickshaw men, Kamekichi MIURA, to use his power for his campaign, and by distributing leaflets saying that participants could enjoy as much sake as they wanted, he gathered many rickshaw men at a get-together party held within the precincts of the Kanda-Myojin Shrine on October 4, 1882.
